section: The Joint Venturers agree and declare that this association for the carrying on of a joint venture business operation does not, and is not intended to create a partnership, for either legal or United States income tax purposes, each Party recognizing that the other is willing and able to contribute capital, labor, and services for the operation of a successful joint venture business. Further, each Party elects under the authority of Section 761(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 (the "Code"), as amended and all successor statutes, to be excluded from the application of all of the provisions of Subchapter K of Chapter 1 of the Subtitle A of the Code, and the Parties agree that the election out of Subchapter K of Chapter 1 of Subtitle A of the Code shall, if necessary, be manifested by their execution and filing of all appropriate documentation.
explanation: While the document states an intent not to create a partnership for tax purposes and elects out of Subchapter K, the structure and operation as described in other sections may legally constitute a partnership regardless of this statement. Specifically, Sections 5 (Powers and Authority of the Joint Venturers) and 6 (Division of Income and Losses) outlines shared control and profit/loss sharing, key elements of a partnership. The IRS or a court could disregard the stated intent if the actual operation reflects a partnership, creating a contradiction between intent and substance.

section: However, in the event of a dispute regarding the valuation of assets during liquidation, Collectible Concepts Group, Inc. will have the final say on the asset's value.
explanation: This clause in Section 11 gives Collectible Concepts Group, Inc. (CCGI) unilateral control over asset valuation during liquidation, which directly contradicts the earlier stated principle of equal sharing of income and losses (Section 6: 50% to each party) and the general principle of joint management. This creates a significant power imbalance that could allow CCGI to unfairly disadvantage Pivotal Self Service Tech, Inc. during liquidation, effectively undermining the equal sharing arrangement and potentially violating fiduciary duties depending on how the Joint Venture is ultimately classified legally. This is an in-text contradiction.

section: The Joint Venture shall commence on the 1st of March, 2003, and shall be effective until February 28, 2004 unless extended by written agreement of the Joint Venturers not less than thirty (30) days prior to scheduled termination. However, either Joint Venturer may unilaterally terminate the agreement with written notice of sixty (60) days.
explanation: This section establishes a fixed term for the joint venture (March 1, 2003, to February 28, 2004) but immediately allows either party to unilaterally terminate the agreement with 60 days' notice. This creates an ambiguity about the actual term of the agreement. The unilateral termination clause effectively negates the purpose of the fixed term, as either party can end the agreement before the scheduled termination date. The condition for an extension of the contract also causes an inconsistency as either party can overrule the agreed extension with a written notice of termination. This is an example of inconsistencies in text and creates an in-text contradiction.
